reviewText:
It has been four years since the last we saw Captain Jack Sparrow in the bloated third film of the Pirates of the Caribbean series, but this time he is back in a stand alone story that has little to do with the previous three. This may be the shortest of the four movies as well (around 2 hours and 15 minutes) and it's never boring, but for some reason it still seems too long. I must admit that I liked Dead Man's Chest and At World's End, but the first one, as with most movie series, will always be the best. On Stranger Tides might even be slightly better than the last two sequels. At least it's not as confusing as At World's End, but I can pretty much say that if you didn't like the last two you'll probably feel the same about this one.

Johnny Depp it seems will keep playing this character until the day he dies. I read that he wants to do at least two more PotC movies. Yes he has created one of the most memorable characters in movie history, but too much of a good thing can turn annoying real quick. I think he fares quite well this time around, more so than the last two, even though Jack Sparrow gets more and more goofy with each outing. Geoffrey Rush is back as Captain Barbossa and has his moments. Ian McShane has the look suited for Blackbeard, the most feared pirate of all time, but they should have made him much taller as was the real man. Depp even towered over him in some scenes, making him less intimidating. He also didn't do as much with this villainous role as I was hoping for. Those who have seen McShane on Deadwood know what I mean. Since Orlando Bloom and Kiera Knightley are gone, Penlope Cruz tries to fill the void as the daughter of Blackbeard. She looks good of course, but there wasn't much chemistry between her and Depp. The addition of mermaids was my favorite part, and these are like no mermaids I've ever heard of. Their beauty lures you in before dragging you underwater to be drowned and devoured.

I read that the budget was half of the last film (around 150 instead of 300 million), but I really didn't notice. The CGI and sets looked up to par. Of course you also will get more than enough of that loud Han Zimmer score that runs through the whole series.

Overall, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is not a great movie and it might leave you with the impression that you have already seen this before, but as a mindless piece of summer entertainment it gets the job done.

Oh, the IMAX 3-D looked really clear, but I'm not sure it was worth double the price.

3 and 1/2 out of 5 stars

This is a review of the movie seen at the theater, NOT the BD release planned for the future.

Chances are if you're reading this you're a fan of the Pirates franchise, and/or Depp and company so are willing to overlook the fact that this is a money spinning exercise set squarely in the "popcorn flick" genre of summer blockbusters.
Much has been made of the absence of Orlando Bloom, and Keira Knightly, in so far as they thought it enough of a ridiculous and unnecessary 4th outing as to not be involved, but the inclusion of Penelope Cruz, and Ian McShane more than make up for that anyway (in my opinion).

This latest, somewhat shorter installment treads much of the same ground as the previous 3 to no surprise, and like them or hate them, you have to agree in part to continuing a winning formula. A critics dream this is not, but of course it will still wow plenty of summer audiences, and no doubt be a financial success.

So to my "muddled" comment. Well the story (which was probably conceived as a good idea somewhere) revolves around Jack Sparrow searching for the fountain of youth.
Tagging along are the ever pleasing Jeffrey Rush as Barbossa chewing scenery as he goes, and arch nemesis Ian McShane as Blackbeard, complete with beautiful daughter Cruz.
Secret silver chalices, CGI mermaids that change from beauty to beast while attacking, and an ever present need for the cast to explain what is going on, just makes the whole thing look muddled.

Depp's antics stretch credulity even more than usual, as does most of the story, from an initial escape (again) to the plot twisting quest. Another criticism for me would be that Cruz and Depp do not have the spark or chemistry they should, probably safer to say that Depp and Rush have more.

Of course it's a PG-13 so the action and eye candy abound. That's probably what saves the movie somewhat, it's less plodding than the previous movies, and as long as you can suspend disbelief enough, you'll enjoy the action sequences that seem to bombard most of the film.

No spoilers here, just accept it for what it is. 3 Stars

The Pirates of the Caribbean films have never pretended to be anything that they're not. Their inspiration was an amusement park ride after all. The films seem to be more of a vehicle for Johnny Depp to step inside of a character he has a little too much fun playing and are aimed toward women (and men, in some cases) who like to oggle him more than anything. The sequels just felt like an already thin premise was stretched beyond its means, which resulted in lackluster sequels that came off as being too similar to the original film. They were still entertaining on some level and people really seem to love the franchise. But you can't expect a new sequel to come along and break the mold, especially when the previous films have made over $2.5 billion at the worldwide box office. On Stranger Tides pretty much offers more of the same for its fans.

The Pirates films have never shied away from action, but On Stranger Tides seems to have even more than the films before it. It's Jack Sparrow's first film away from Will Turner and Elizabeth Swann, so some over the top antics can probably be expected. Most of the film felt like an episode of "The Dukes of Hazzard" except it was centered around Jack Sparrow instead of the Duke boys and revolved around the open sea and The Black Pearl instead of Hazzard county and General Lee. Most of the scenes could basically be described in that voice over that'd say something along the lines of, "Jack's sure gotten himself into one heck of a pickle this time. How in the world will he swashbuckle his way out of this one?"

With Jack worming his way out of several crazy situations and nearly non-stop swordplay and action, the film's cast could probably be considered better than decent. Geoffrey Rush and Kevin McNally are the only returning cast members from the previous films other than Depp and they slide back into the Barbossa and Gibbs characters just as easily as Depp channels Jack Sparrow. Angelica, played by Penelope Cruz, was a little too convenient of a character. A former love interest of Jack's who hasn't forgiven or forgotten the way things ended between them. Their relationship and the way things pan out between them just seemed rather predictable in the long run. Ian McShane was pretty disappointing, as well. He's given this incredibly cool character in Blackbeard. All pirates fear him; he has this awesome pirate ship, and can bring men back from the dead. He even has a few memorable one liners, but the guy couldn't have looked more bored during the entire film. Johnny Depp looks to be the only guy actually having fun in this film while everyone else just sees it as another job. On Stranger Tides still has an entertaining vibe to it, but also feels like a film we've seen three times before.

Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is familiar territory. By now you should have a good idea of whether or not you'll enjoy the film or not. It follows the same formula as the previous three films, but is the shortest of the films and seems to be lacking a story that really reels you in. Audiences love Johnny Depp, so there's no doubt it'll be a success. The action does seem to be amped up a bit, but Jack Sparrow seems goofier than ever. It's humorous at times, but similar to Homer getting dumber in every new season of "The Simpsons." While the film wasn't a huge home run with critics, it's still the explosive and extravagant return of a character everyone loves and is bound to set the box office on fire once again.

Among the Pirates anthology this was clearly the worst. Entertaining, but nothing Ill choose to watch again.

So much has changed over the course of four Pirates movies. Now pledged to the crown, we find a bewigged Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush; Gods of Egypt, The Warriors Way, The Kings Speech), peg-legging about complete with make-up, explaining how he lost the Black Pearl.  Much as did Norrington in parts 1-2, Barbossas allegiance his shifted dramatically.  But were used to that in this franchise, aren't we?

Picking up where At Worlds End (2007) left off, Captain Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp; Blow) endeavors to find the Fountain of Youth, and he must do so before the Spanish find it first!

Jack needs a ship, and finds opportunity when rumors of another Jack Sparrow (an imposter) signing on new crew members.  This imposter is Angelica (Penelope Cruz; Blow, Vanilla Sky), Jacks ex-girlfriend and the first mate of the sorcerous Captain Blackbeard (Ian McShane; Jack the Giant Slayer, John Wick 2).  Interesting how undeath seems to be a theme throughout the Pirates films.  Rumored to have returned from the dead, Blackbeard has created zombified crewmen and wields a magical control of his ship.

To reap the gifts of the Fountain of Youth requires a mermaid (Astrid Bergès-Frisbey; King Arthur: Legend of the Sword). Only one problem: mermaids are ferocious man-eaters.  The mermaid attack scene was outstandingly fun.

Director Rob Marshall (Chicago, Memoirs of a Geisha) picks up the fourth installment of the Pirates anthology after Gore Verbinskis original trilogy. So, what does that mean for us? Well, nothing good really.  Our senses are no longer dazzled by Verbinskis realization of grand scale.  And this loss of scale is not limited to the cinescapes, but the execution.  Jacks stunt-rich shenanigans are fine, but seem just mildly entertaining iterations compared to his past films.  And whereas the swordplay choreography itself was on point, the overall scenes and fights lacked impact.  Moreover, whereas many ship sets looked excellent (as is the mega-budget franchise standard), several other sets (e.g., the caverns) felt as if they spawned from a far lower budget filmcertainly not the product of a $250 million blockbuster!  Its as if we set up our coolers and lawn chairs at dusk awaiting fireworks only to be met with sparklers.  And speaking of sparklers, this was the first Pirates film that had no significant ship-to-ship combat!

It doesnt help, for my taste anyway, that everything seems sillier in this sequel. We have silly disguises (many times over), silly balancing gags (like a teetering ship), silly escape gags (like climbing a tree backwards and sling-shoting oneself), silly maneuver gags (like tying up 8 men at once by running around them with a rope like a cartoon character) is this to make this more kid-friendly? I even had to watch a completely forced man-mermaid love connection transpire, boasting no more chemistry than that between a man and an actual fish.  Wheres Will and Elizabeth when we need them?  Their love was credible.

On the other hand, the plot is not overly complicated.  The double-crosses were few, and the story was followable without having seen The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003) and Dead Mans Chest (2006), like yesterday, in order to have a clue whats going onwhich was the case with the confounding At Worlds End (2007).  Another perk was that, as usual, the ships look fantastic.  I always loved how every captains ship had as much personality in appearance as the men crewing them.  But, with that, another downer: we lost many members of the crew we had come to love and the tentacled effects we came to love!  Oh, right, and why was this Fountain of Youth plot even important???  There was really never a good reason to find the fountain outside of greed.  Ergo, no urgency for us to care.

Overall, this was a dud. Its a huge budget popcorn movie and I didn't exactly hate watching it as a standalone filmunlike the overly prequel-reliant parts 2 or 3but this was the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull of the Pirates anthology. We all know its there, but none of us want to acknowledge its existence after weve seem it.  Id suggest the next time you watch the original trilogy, skip to Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017) and ignore this one.

I really enjoyed the first Pirates film, it was a pirate movie in a time where no one was making pirate films. It had it's flaws but it was an enjoyable ride. I found the second movie to be fine, and I really disliked the third. On Stranger Tides is a return to form in a lot of ways. I don't know if Jack Sparrow should be the main character, as great as Depp is in the role it's a little overkill at times, but this movie goes back to the basics from the first film. It's a smaller, more contained story without all of the heavy handed drama the second and third films wallowed in. It's a silly, fun movie that doesn't take itself too seriously. Sometimes that's just fine.

Really wanted to like this but it misses the magic made in the the previous 3. Im sure its the directors changing that caused this but it seemed to have different lighting, coloring, angles and basic story line that seemed to have so much more potential. I loved the story but some of the bits (shadowed fight between Jack and "Jack") were a bit silly, even for this series. What I missed was the previously present musical score that seemed to be not as upfront. Same composer but seemed subdued. We will see if the direction changes or stays the same for #5

First and foremost, I offer NO spoilers. Just a quick and honest opinion of the quality and watchability.

 Pirates OTC has got to be one of the coolest movies out there period! We as a family have enjoyed every single iteration of this series of movies! they just keep getting better! After each one we are like just praying that there will be another and this one in particular left us wanting more! The acting is hilarious, the screen play is exciting and we are taken on an adventure every time! Being able to enjoy this one in 3D was a real treat to the eyes and senses. Please keep in mind that not all 3D TV's are made the same and some do a much better job at rendering 3D than others. Luckily we have a very nice 65" 3D TV that does an excellent job at rendering the most perfect 3D image possible, and in turn we get to enjoy 3D as it is intended to be viewed! So if you have a good 3D TV I would suggest getting this in 3d and enjoying the treat it offers. Also I need to point out that some 3D movies are not done well or done right. However, this one was done VERY well, and done right too!
 If your a POTC fan, then don't hesitate and jump right into this one, you'll be glad you did!

You know there are times when critics really piss me off and you can tell when they are just out for blood because they didn't like the last movie or because they don't appreciate comedy which a lot of them do not. I'm not going to make this too long as a matter fact I'm going to make this as easy as possible. Do you remember the magic of the first film and the way that that film made you feel and laugh and how it sucked you into the story? Then I would most definitely watch this movie because this movie more than any of the sequels reminded me of the first movie again and what made it so good. To me they kind of lost a little something in part 2 and especially in part 3. But in this movie that magic that the first film had really seems to be back and Johnny Depp is 100% back into the character we know and love. The actors shine in this movie as a matter of fact the acting is excellent and anyone who says any different didn't really bother to watch the film. Hands down the best film since the original and I'm hoping that the next one follows the same suit. As far as entertainment goes this movie really delivers on all fronts and I honestly had a very hard time finding any failures. The only major failure is the fact that the critics ever had the opportunity to review this film because they were dead wrong. As they often are. Be your own critic, watch the film and enjoy the resurrection of Jack Sparrow.

Let's pick a narrative and stick with it. All of the movies in the franchise suffer from this schizophrenic universe. It's like the script was written by Gloria Steinem and Simone de Beauvoir. I can't figure out how I'm supposed to feel sorry for the women in the story. Am I supposed to celebrate her female empowerment while dealing with boneheaded men, or feel feel the need to protect her when she faints or does some other girly thing? Is beauty of women really what's important, while you leave your own father to suffer for eternity while you go chase some tail? Is that really what is so important? Do what Captain Jack Sparrow does, find some other girls. Granted, Jack could lose the womanizing.
I passed over all the contrived coincidences and cop-outs but it got really tiring with the excessive narm before I have a chance to start believing the story. The political message is so overt that it's chronically distracting and none of the characters except Jack is likable. It's not that I hate the actors, I think they actors did a great job convincing me, but I think the character design was so contrived that I just couldn't believe it. Also, why is a girl fighting a bunch of men and not losing? Sorry, but there's a huge strength advantage. I can't be bought with any line to the contrary since even in universe, the women demonstrate female tropes as fragility and neediness.
Too much contrived love for any sort of action movie, this movie demonstrates. I want to watch a fight, even though the fights are hard to believe, but why are we interrupting my movie to for a piece of love-plot that doesn't have any real bearing on the outcome? If some girl doesn't want to wait for me to finish a fight before we get married, we're not getting married (OK, that's for a previous movie, but still, it's the universe).
I couldn't stomach the second half of the movie. Way too much narm, way too much unbelievable love story, and too many cop-outs. This really makes for a water thin plot.
Sometimes, I ask myself, did Micheal Bayes make this movie? Some of these scenes remind me of Michael's movies (memories of which I am not fond). It makes me wonder why mental illnesses the director suffers, because I suspect these struggles bleeding into the movie.

Say what you will (Disney = moneygrubbers, Johnny Depp = washed up), but one of the most recent and fun franchises around is the Pirates of the Caribbean series. On Stranger Tides continues the adventures of Captain Jack Sparrow, picking up from what was alluded to at the end of At World's End. We get to see the irrepressible Capt. Hector Barbossa, this time "in the services of" King George as a privateer (spoiler alert, once a pirate, always a pirate) as well as Mr. Gibbs and a couple of returning His Majesty's Royal Navy officers (RIP). Definitely not my favorite in the series (that'll always be Curse of the Black Pearl), but a worthy addition to the series. I'm eagerly looking returning to the high seas in next year's Dead Men Tell No Tales!

I wasn't sure I'd want this sequel. The 3rd movie nearly did me in for the entire series, but pirates, man. They get me every time. I blame it on growing up and riding the ride at Disney back in the day.

I digress. I wouldn't say this movie was without its flaws, but I think it's a good starting point for a divergence of Jack--which is actually what I had originally WANTED with the actual sequel (#2, that is). We learn a lot about Jack in this movie. We learn a lot about the people around Jack as well. And we kind of get a sense for how he turned out to be like he is. Not everything, of course--Jack remains, still, quite the complicated fellow--but a lot.

And the rest of the characters, old (like Barbossa) and new (like our lovely love interest), are fantastic. My only complaint about the series is that they still enjoy telling without showing, and they rarely like telling you the whole back story.

But Jack still remains my favorite pirate, and that is, quite frankly, that. I'm actually looking forward to the next.

I remember not thinking too much of this film when I first saw it in theaters. The story seemed to go nowhere. The characters had worn out their welcome. The "Pirates" brand was all but burned out.

Upon recent repeat viewings my opinion has somewhat changed. Ian McShane does a pretty good job with Blackbeard, and the dynamic with his daughter is fairly believable. In fact his introduction upon Queen Anne's Revenge is the highlight of the film. Johnny Depp does... What Depp does best: method acting ad infinitum. Geoffrey Rush continues to chew up the scenery in just about every scene he's in. You could argue it's just as much his movie as it is Depp's.

The special effects are pretty good and the movie looks good in 3d (I'm watching with active 3D). I think the movie tends to suffer in its third act where there is a lull where not much is accomplished. Also the music is pretty enjoyable, as is with most of the film's in the series. I think the movie could have benefitted with some more emphasis on the Inquisition but that's just me.

Overall not a terrible film but not great either. This is a solid Blu ray however with good audio/visual quality. I can't comment on the supplements. It's worth a watch if you enjoyed the other movies.

Having heard none of the bad reviews for this previously (and quite honestly forgetting it's existence entirely until last week) I was fully expecting to absolutely love this like I have the others...

What I got was crappy fanfiction.

What reason are we given to care about ANY of these characters, even/ especially the existing ones such as Barbossa, or even Jack himself?

Why are there suddenly so many bland, boring, uninteresting AF characters whose names no one even knows because by the time it's mentioned you're just blankly staring at the screen?

Are we actually supposed to care for Angelica or the Missionary (whose name is Phillip, which I only know because subtitles), or hell, are we even supposed to care for the mermaid past how beautiful she is?

Where has //my// Captain Jack Sparrow gone, my autistic Captain who managed to sway the hearts and loyalties all around him even as he snuck and danced around, managing to free or entangle our heroes from or in various near-death scenarios? Where is the Jack who would have suggested "Y'know, why don't we just /ask/ the mermaid for her tears? Why not make a deal that is beneficial for everyone?" Instead of standing by as a girl is tortured for a single teardrop. What exactly was the entire 15 minute thing with the cliff and the broken bridge? Who are we supposed to be rooting for in that final battle? Why even bother bringing in the Spanish fleet as villains if they have like, five minutes of screentime. I just... I do not understand how this movie was made, let alone how anyone could have standard to watch in theaters for the entire, dragging, 2 hours that seemed like 4, and not in the good way few movies achieve. I'm now regretting that I bought it instead of renting it, as I will absolutely never rewatch this which has effectively killed one of favorite movie series, and sincerely hope that no other movies are made after this-- something I would have been appalled to think just two and a half hours ago. The only redemption this movie could have in a sequel would be to retcon it as a dream Jack or Barbossa or whoever had while trapped chasing down the real fountain of youth...

This movie is very good! The new characters and the addition of King George II, the mermaids, and a love interest for Jack Sparrow ( Excuse me, Captain Jack Sparrow) are unexpected, but I like them. I am biased because I like the other movies in the series, but this movie is so different that I would like it anyways. One of the best parts is in the beginning what Captain Jack is listening to King George. The king talks and talks of the fountain of youth and how he needs help from Captain Jack, who is annoying the king with his noisy handcuffs. When Captain Jack is free, all the viewers know that the shenanigans will begin. Another reason that this part is the best? Captain Barbossa is back. In my opinion, he is better in this movie, maybe because we see his soft side. The scene with the leaning ship is very exciting, and also the scene where Captain Jack climbs a coconut tree to escape the Spanish. Every scene that Captain Jack and Barbossa are in together is a great one. In general, this movie is amazing and I will watch it again.

Right up front, I have to make an admission: This is a rather
difficult review to write.  You see, I was never a fan of the
Pirates of the Caribbean franchise.  While I certainly have
enjoyed its big-budgeted swashbuckling adventures of pirates
and treasure hunting -- I still have not come to terms with
Johnny Depp's portrayal of Jack Sparrow.  I find nothing
charming nor funny about this buffoon of a character who
basically spends the entire film mumbling through dialogue
to the point where he is basically incoherent.

Of course, my opinion of the Jack Sparrow character will not
be a popular one.  The Pirates of the Caribbean franchise has
been a huge success for Disney, with this fourth installment
grossing $2.7 billion worldwide.  Not bad for a film series
based on a theme park ride.  Unfortunately, Disney continues
to capitalize on a franchise that ran out of steam long after
the first two installments.

In Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides we find Captain
Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) and his arch-rival Hector Barbossa
(Geoffrey Rush) in competition to find the lost fountain of youth.
Along the way Sparrow gets caught up with the notorious
Blackbeard (Deadwood's Ian McShane) and his manipulative
daughter, Angelica (Penelope Cruz).  Filled with enormous,
big-budgeted backdrop scenery, the action takes us through a
daring escape across the streets of London to a mutiny onboard
the Queen Anne's Revenge upon the high seas.

As with most of the Pirate films, the length of the movie seems
rather bloated, with lots of padding given to the film's action
sequences.  Really, the only real highlight of this film happens
halfway through in a sequence involving a group of enchanting,
but vicious mermaids.  It's enough to wake you from the blandness
that proceeds it, but unfortunately, the film struggles to regain
momentum moving forward.  To make matters worse, Jack
Sparrow isn't the only character mumbling through his dialogue.
The actors speak with such thick accents that it was necessary
for me to turn on the subtitles to understand what was being spoken.

The 1080p transfer is outstanding, for the most part.  Shot on
location in Hawaii and Puerto Rico, the gorgeous tropical locations
benefit from a detailed transfer that exploits its lush coloration.
Black levels are nice and deep, too.  No artifacts to be found
anywhere. Unfortunately, most of the films cinematography is
hampered by its many gloomy interior scenes.....

...which brings me to the 3D presentation.  It's almost pointless.
Because much of the film takes place in dull, low-light surroundings,
the presentation looks mostly flat.  It certainly won't help that on some
displays that don't properly compensate for dimming, glasses are going
to worsen the dulling effect.  Interestingly enough, I saw virtually no
introduction of ghosting which usually plagues films like these.
When the movie does open up to its bright, outdoor locales, there
seems to be a sense of depth, but it's quite minimal.

The film's "In Yo' Face" factor is reduced to a few gimmicky moments
that involve swords that slightly poke themselves out at the audience.
Meanwhile, there are so many lost opportunities with props that could
have easily been enhanced for the format including firing cannons and
a slithering water snake.  While some of the outdoor scenes are purposely
shot behind jungle foliage, the overall effect it provides is insignificant.

Perhaps this film's most notable feature is it's 7.1 DTS-HD track that
was downcoverted to 5.1 on my system.  This is a powerhouse of
a soundtrack that features an unbelievable amount of dynamic range
and sense of spatiality. The particular placement of surround activity
is just amazing to hear -- most evident in a scene aboard Ponce de
Leòne's ship where the groaning and grunts of a vessel being kept
in balance creates an 360-degree soundfield that is quite impressive.
I was very pleased with the LFE activity here that underlines the
on-screen action and pounding drum score that accompanies it.

Pirates of the Caribean: On Stranger Tides arrives in a 5-disc
combo set that includes the 3D Blu-ray Feature Film, the 2D
Blu-ray Feature Film + Bonus, Blu-ray standalone bonus disc,
DVD Feature Film + Bonus and a Digital Copy of the Feature
Film.  All of this is housed in lenticular "limited edition" packaging.

This Limited Edition 5-disc Blu-ray combo pack includes hours
of bonus material that includes immersive Disney Second Screen
Technology, exclusive behind-the-scenes experiences, Fountain
of Youth mythology, an extensive look at mermaids, bloopers,
deleted and extended scenes (to name a few).

I should also mention that there are 3D trailers included for
John Carter and Cars 2.

Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is what I hope is a close
to a franchise that was worn out long ago.  Those that are tempted to
purchase this Blu-ray may not want to consider the 3D upgrade as it
really offers very little over its 2D counterpart.

Recommended for rental only.

I hated At Worlds End the first time I watched it in movie theaters. The next time I watched it, I found that I enjoyed it. Now, it is actually one of my favorite movies. Yes, it has some writing flaws. But it takes a lot of chances, and oftentimes big budget releases won't do that. I honestly didn't have any preconcieved notions about On Stranger Tides, but I was worried about the state of the franchise minus Orlando Bloom and Kiera Knightly. All in all, I found this to be a fun offering. Did it continue in the epic tradition of the first three? Yes, but not entirely. I thought the love story arc, mixed with Jack Sparrow's comedy, overlayed with treasure, curses, famous ships, and a world in transition really made for a compelling narrative. One bright spot was Penelope Cruz. I thought she added a nice dynamic opposite Depp.

Finally got around to watching this. I am pretty much squarely in the three star camp: I liked many things about the film, but thought it had several problems, too. A couple of random thoughts: What's with the light hair and orange-looking tan on Captain Sparrow? (I tried it on more than one device, and it looked like that on all of them.) It's distractingly odd looking, as if the costumers did not see the first three movies. If they did it on purpose for some reason, it didn't really work. They should have left his hair dark, but sprinkled in some gray and also added a touch of gray to his beard--he would look freaking awesome.

That leads me to my second thought: the characters and actors are aging and the movie should have embraced that more than it did, developing the theme, already alluded to several times in previous episodes, of a changing world and the approaching end of the pirate era. The conversation between Jack and Barbossa standing by the dead Kraken, Barbossa's comment about their sands running out, even the conversation between Jack and Gibbs on the beach at the end of this latest film (a very nice ending, by the way), are examples of things that could all be brought together more coherently and drive the plot, dialogue, and character's choices. We could use a few more quiet conversations and fewer sword fights on rafters. Jack Sparrow could continue to represent the desire for freedom and the view that it is selling out to embrace the colonial governments and corporations/trading companies just because they are on the "winning side," but he could admit that his cause may be eventually lost. Don't we often admire those dedicated to a lost cause?

We'll see what they do with Pirates 5, but I hope it is not their intention to just keep going, like the James Bond franchise, replacing Johnny Depp (as if!) with new actors to play Jack Sparrow for years to come. Let's end the series with a little dignity.

This movie was obviously set up by the final couple scenes of At World's End, when they tease the Fountain Of Youth story.  This picks up at some point after with Jack and Gibbs in London, running into Barbossa, who now works for the crown.  They all end up in a race with Blackbeard and the Spanish to find the Fountain.  Intertwined in the story is Penelope Cruz's character who has a past both with Jack and Blackbeard.  Much of the cast from the original trilogy are not present in this movie (including Orlando Bloom and Kiera Knightly).  The main "supernatural" characters in this movie come in the form of mermaids, who appear about halfway in.

Overall, the film takes the darker tones from the second and third movies of the "main" trilogy.  While it does have some humorous and lighthearted moments, they are not as frequent as in the first film.  There are, of course, a lot of action sequences and CGI work.  The CG in the film looks great, but it does seem that they did what they could to build real sets so not everything was CG.  There was probably more suggested sexual content in this movie (although nothing overt) than in all the others.  Thankfully they kept the running time to just over 2hrs and it did not feel like it was dragging like At World's End seemed to.

For those that get the actual discs, this movie is the lightest on extras of all of them.  There is no separate disc with bonus features, everything is included on the movie disc.  The "big" extra is the ability to play the movie with the in movie experience that pops up windows throughout the movie that allow you to get a deeper insight into the film.  Then there is a blooper reel, a few deleted scenes and a few behind the scenes features.  Of course the movie looks and sounds great as you would expect.

If you are a big fan of all the Pirates movies, then this will be worth adding to your collection.  If you fall into the camp where you liked the first movie and started to get sick of them by the third one, then you are probably not going to like this enough to buy it.  There is not a ton of character development throughout the film, save for the few new characters that show up, but it mostly relies on the assumption you know who everyone is.  The story is good, but not as good or fun as in Curse of the Black Pearl, so if that is the only movie in the series you really liked then you may want to limit yourself to just having this on in the background.  Otherwise, I do think it is a worthwhile addition.

I enjoyed watching "On Stranger Tides"

Let's face it, everyone goes to see the Pirates of the Caribbean movies for one reason - Captain Jack Sparrow.  And that's why, if Disney was going to continue the franchise, it made sense to relaunch it focused more on Jack.  And that's just what they've done with On Stranger Tides.  It still doesn't quite recapture the magic of the first one, but it's fun.

On story opens in London where Captain Jack (Johnny Depp) is surprised to learn that he is outfitting a ship with a crew for a new voyage.  Since Jack is currently without ship or crew, it's quite a shock.  Confronting the imposter, he learns it is Angelica (Penelope Cruz), a fling from his past.

Next thing Jack knows, he's been shanghaied on the Queen Anne's Revenge, the ship of the pirate all pirates fear, Blackbeard (Ian McShane).  He is in search of the fabled fountain of youth and thinks Jack has a map.  To complicate things, the Spanish have also launched an expedition to find it, and the British have enlisted Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) to claim it first.  Will any of these groups find the fountain?

Those hoping for lots of Captain Jack will be thrilled because this is his movie.  The scenes without him are few and far between.  Johnny Depp is in find form here and easily cares the move with his antics as the title character.

The movie feels like it has been pulled back from the wild excesses of the second and third in the series, which is a good thing.  Those movies, while they had their moments, felt more like excuses for special effects held together by the thinnest of plots.  Here, we actually get a coherent story again.  I wouldn't say the characters are fully developed, but they work for the piece.

My only real gripe with the film is the pacing.  It's over two hours, and it felt it.  Actually, I feel like they could have easily cut out the Spanish without changing much at all in the film.  A little more comedy might have helped as well.

While the special effects have been toned back, they are still present and very well done.  I had no trouble buying anything I saw on the screen.

The rest of the cast has a challenge making themselves obvious opposite Johnny Depp, and they do a good job.  In addition to Depp and Geoffrey Rush, Kevin McNally is also back as first mate Gibbs.  I had a lot of fun watching the three of them on screen again.  The new to the franchise cast brings their characters to life and make memorable contributions to the movie.  I will say I missed Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner, but as the longer the movie went on, the less I even though about them.

In many ways, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is a reboot of the franchise.  If you haven't seen the others, there is little here that will confuse you.  Yet if you are already a fan, you'll find yourself on another fun pirate ride.

To begin with, I absolutely love the Pirates of the Caribbean series of movies and have watched On Stranger Tide probably two dozen times, if not more (I travel a lot). I ordered the 3D version after buying a Sony 65" 3D 4K HDTV this month. Watching this movie in 3D was almost like watching for the first time. The majority of the movie was remarkable. There were parts that I paused and/or played in slow motion just to take it the effects.

I am very new to the 3D experience and to date have watched Avatar, Gamer and this movie on my TV. So far I have observed that scenes where the production crew had a camera in a fixed position have the best 3D effect. This movie has a lot of those making it a great experience. Movies like Gamer where the camera and the objects/people being filmed are moving degrade the 3D effect and make it hard for the eyes to keep up. Fast moving action scenes will lose some of the 3D effect but the majority of the movie was absolutely captivating.
Good 3D effects.

This fourth installment is a prequel.  Since that has never been done--ever...let me begin by explaining my expectations.  Prequels normally provide insight into the character that it is centered around.  The story follows that individual and you learn more about how he/she became the way he/she is in the other movies.

This story doesn't do that--we see Jack Sparrow doing most of his old tricks from the first Pirates of the Caribbean movie, with little explanation of what is going on.  The plot is rushing from one thing to the next for two hours.  This reboot/prequel, doesn't do the original justice, but provides enough entertainment (carried by Johnny Deep) to be worth a watch or two--but high marks I wouldn't give it.

This movie is a textbook example of a GOOD sequel. It avoids all of the mistakes that the first two POTC sequels made. In my own personal canon, this is the ONLY sequel. Why? Well, I'll give you a rundown...

* It keeps with the mood of the first movie

The first "Pirates of the Caribbean" was, first and foremost, an adventure movie. Yes, it had dark elements; but it didn't take itself too seriously. The modern special effects and action sequences notwithstanding, it had the spunk and camp of old-school, classic pirate adventures like "Treasure Island" and "Captain Blood." The first two sequels on the other hand, "Dead Man's Chest" and "At World's End," abandoned all of that in favor of the "darker and edgier" style of storytelling that was all the rage in the mid-to-late '00s. Those sequels hardly even seemed to be about pirates; instead, the focus was on over-the-top green-screen monsters, whose victims sort of just happened to be pirates. Blech.

THIS movie on the other hand goes right back to the mood of the first one. It's got dark elements sure, but only for the sake of the moment; the green-screen monsters here are for the thrills, not to try and trick you into taking a pirate movie seriously. There is far more emphasis on the sword fights, the treasure hunts, mutinies, privateering, and, well PIRATEY stuff. Jack Sparrow is also back in character.  And the new villain, Blackbeard, is much more like a classic pirate villain than Davey Jones. But those are two points all on their own...

* Jack Sparrow is back in character

One thing that was so wrong with the last two sequels was how they butchered Jack's character. In the first movie Jack was a lovable rogue, a pirate who was self-serving when it came to superficial things like money, but heroic where it really mattered. The Jack Sparrow who dove into the water to save Elizabeth Swan from drowning would never have done or said half of the selfish, cowardly things they had him do in the second and third movies. In the first movie, a huge emphasis was put on the fact that Jack was "a pirate...and a good man." In "Dead Man's Chest" Jack has suddenly forgotten he's a good man, and is reduced to a flat "bad guy who must learn to have basic morals" cliche. Insulting.

"Stranger Tides" is completely back on track with Jack's character. Sure he's self-serving when it comes to avoiding jail time and leaving his buddy Gibbs to rot in prison; but when he knows someone's life is on the line, Jack risks his own skin to do what's right. (I'm talking about the moment when Blackbeard demands, "Who kept watch?" and Jack quickly lies, in an attempt to protect an unnamed man, "I did sir, I kept watch!") The concern Jack shows for Angelica, as she's manipulated by her sociopath father Backbeard, is also much more on par with the Jack who was a quasi-mentor to Will Turner in the first movie.

* The villain is neither "sympathetic" nor green-screened.

Don't get me wrong; when done well, a sympathetic villain is great. But Davey Jones wasn't done well. I mean, come on... is angsting over a flighty girlfriend really supposed to make us sympathetic to a murderous villain? Pfft. And the gross tentacle face, just...no. A human face with real emotion and mannerisms ALWAYS makes a more compelling villain than a CGI effect.

Blackbeard is very much the new Barbossa of this movie. (Barbossa's in this movie, yes, but since he's given up villainy to be an antihero, someone else has to step up to bat.) Of course, Blackbeard isn't identical to Barbossa. Where Barbossa was wild-eyed and gruff, Blackbeard is slow and calculating. But like Barbossa in the first movie, Blackbeard is a cut-throat, merciless pirate, plain and simple. The movie even makes a theme out of Blackbeard's one-dimensional evil, with "Not every villain can be 'saved.'"

This and the first movie are proof that one-dimensional villains are not always a bad thing. Because in real life, some people ARE just sociopaths. And if such evil can be portrayed by a great actor full of pizzazz, so much the better. These types of villains are a far better fit for a pirate franchise than the angsting, "pity me!" CGI monster we had in the last two sequels.

* It's its own story

A bad sequel takes a good movie that had perfect closure and says, "Wait! Actually, that wasn't the end! The heroes DIDN'T get to live happily ever after, they had to suffer through two more movies worth of bulls***!" A good sequel, on the other hand, says, "Here's an example of some stuff that could have happened after that adventure." It doesn't need to drag all of the main characters from the first movie back into another adventure. It doesn't feel the need to "out-do" the first movie, or "continue" the story. It just tells ANOTHER story, a DIFFERENT story.

"Stranger Tides" leaves Will, Elizabeth, Port Royal, and even the Black Pearl behind. This movie focuses on a sort of space-race between England, Spain, and Blackbeard, to reach the Fountain of Youth. Other plot twists, like Angelica being manipulated by her father, Barbossa becoming a privateer, and a Christian missionary falling in love with a mermaid, are all a welcome change from Will and Elizabeth's tired love story. The one aspect of this movie that does seem very familiar is Barbossa's quest to avenge his (seemingly) lost ship. But instead of hoping the audience has amnesia, the movie twists the familiarity to it's advantage, creating a great moment where Jack to shows empathy for his old rival, as they're forced to team up against Blackbeard.

* A fresh cast

Like I said above, a good sequel doesn't try to force all of the same characters back into the fray. It brings back a few old characters, and introduces new ones, according to what fits the story. "On Stranger Tides" allows Will and Elizabeth to just live out the rest of their lives (finally). But since Barbossa and Jack are still playing tug-of-war over the Pearl, they're bound to cross paths again. And naturally, Jack's crazy schemes aren't much fun without Gibbs' apprehension.

Along with a new villain, this movie gives us new heroes (that is, straight-up good guys, to balance Jack's anti-hero antics), a new female lead, and new comic relief. All of which are improvements. I've already explained why Blackbeard is an improvement over Davey Jones. Angelica is a good, fresh female lead over Elizabeth, and Phillip and Syrena are a good new romantic pair, as opposed to bringing Will and Elizabeth back. (Will and Elizabeth were likable enough for the first movie, but their romantic bickering got old by movie 2. And besides, they had a perfect ending in the first movie; why couldn't the writers just let them be?) Angelica's fiery rage and wit were a welcome change from Elizabeth's posh practicality; and the missionary and the mermaid was an interesting romantic twist. Oh, and the comic relief? Forgive me, but Pintel and Ragetti got VERY repetitive in the sequels. I can only see so many fake-eye gags before it stops being funny. Stephen Graham's Scrum was yet another welcome change.

Oh, and the king. The late Richard Griffiths was HILARIOUS as King George. A One Scene Wonder if there ever was one!

* The soundtrack

As soon as the movie ended, my mom said, "I WANT this soundtrack! I love that Spanish guitar!" It's not often that I agree with my mother on something, and man is she right on this one. The soundtrack to this movie ROCKS.

* MERMAIDS

....are one of the most snubbed fantasy creatures in history. And on the rare occasion that they are used in cinema, they are all too often painted as one of two extremes; either all-innocent princesses like Ariel, or else straight-up monsters, like the ones seen in "Harry Potter," or the 2003 version of "Peter Pan." As a hardcore mermaid fan, I highly approve of their portrayal in "Stranger Tides." They're not fully good or evil, just a force of nature that shouldn't be reckoned with. They're enchantingly beautiful, with eerily beautiful singing voices, but also deadly. Their magical powers are implied and hinted at, but never outright revealed, keeping them mysterious. Astrid Berges Frisbey and Gemma Ward are perfect as Syrena and Tamara respectively.

VERDICT:

A damn good sequel. In my personal canon, this is the ONLY sequel. I imagine that Will and Elizabeth lived happily ever after after movie 1, Jack never lost his soft side, and the two middle movies were just a drunken dream of Jack's. Granted, that would leave the question of how Barbossa came back from the dead, but who cares. Magic, scallywags.

With the announcement of a fifth movie though, I'm apprehensive. I only pray that the next movie doesn't go right back into the sequelitis...

With so many sequels out there on films where I haven't even had the desire to see the original (Kung Fu
Panda? Really?), I was about to boycott all summer sequels. But I had to see Pirates of the Caribbean:
On Stranger Tides. When the first pirates came out in 2003, it was love at first "arrrrgh!" Depp was one of
the most endearing pirates ever as Jack Sparrow, and Geoffrey Rush was remarkable as Captain
Barbossa. To say it is one of my favorite pirate movies is an understatement. So when they produced a
sequel a few years later, I was excited--then terribly disappointed. The second installment and for that
matter, the third one which was released just one year later were scattered at best, stretching for a story
that just wasn't understandable or engaging. Terrible.
Now theres Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides. The premise is simple--Barbossa (now in
service to the King of England) and Jack Sparrow are in search of the Fountain of Youth. How to drink
from the Fountain is not so simple--and in that is where this film is redeemed. It would seem that the
producers of Pirates have decided to pull back, regroup, and keep the plot less complicated yet with the
same simple twists that made the first film so enjoyable. Add to the mix Ian McShane, who masterfully
plays the legendary Blackbeard, and you've got the makings of an installment finally worth (although not
fully comparable to) the original. Penelope Cruz is also new to the series, there isn't the same chemistry
between her and Depp as with former lead actress Kiera Knightley (who said that the franchise was
exciting at the time but behind her now).

The entire movie felt as though it was written, produced, and directed by a fan instead of professionals.  Everything about Jack and Barbosa just felt. . .off.  The hair and makeup were wrong, the lines and mannerisms were out of whack, everything.  Even the film quality seemed like it was done on a Flip camera or filmed with someone's iPhone.  Now, while I can normally get behind something that has an Indy-quality feel to it, the story itself was poorly written, the fight choreography was lousy (Medival Times does a better job) and the editing flat-out sucked.  Not to mention the horrible lighting.  Seriously, give this one a pass; the Star Wars prequels were better.

Overall though, great movie, good to see Cap'n Jack back in action!

When I heard that they were making another pirates of the Caribbean movie, I new in the back of my mind that Disney couldn't come up with a new flagship movie in time to replace Pirates, so they decided to stretch out this movie further than should have and it shows.

First off it's painfully slow and it seems very disjointed at times, also they don't give you enough of a reason to care for any of the characters. Jack has run his course and his drunkin personality is getting real old now, Angelica, the love interest for Jack is a very boring character and only serves to cause sexual tension, and Blackbeard is your average sociopathic antagonist with no personality. The leader of the Spaniards was more interesting than the entire cast combined, and they were only on screen for like 15 minutes!

The story was absolutely pointless, it adds nothing to the series. Just a bunch of random escape scenes, mosh pit battles, and dialogue that has been overused way too many times by Barbosa and Jack.

All in all, this is an average popcorn flick, rental at best. At worlds end was a perfect conclusion to the series in my opinion.

I guess you can't expect much from the fourth version of a movie based upon a theme park ride,but I have enjoyed the other Pirate movies.  While this movie had potential you just don't care about the new characters.  Really there is a cleric that travels with Black Beard who falls in love with a mermaid who tries to eat him.  Not exactly a plot that keeps you wanting more.  There's no more Orlando Bloom or Kiera Knightly.  My main complaint about this film is how dark it is.  Dark in that there is very little light for you to see the characters through half or more of the movie.  I would suggest you watch another movie as you'll likely be disappointed with this one.  Sorry for typos as I'm on a mobile device.

The usual Johnny Depp humor and Disney special effects, but I really enjoyed the inclusion of the subplot between the gallant young missionary and the helpless captive mermaid! It was refreshing to see some references to a moral God and the struggle between good and evil. It seemed almost historical rather than the usual Hollywood moral vacuum. The selfless young hero was a welcome contrast to the jaded and self absorbed main character. The well developed theme of mermaids taken from maritime lore was fascinating, but it could be frightening to younger children. This is not the "H2O Just Add Water" variety of mermaid. This set it apart from all the others and made it my favorite of the whole Pirates of the Caribbean series!

So far as 3D and sound quality is concerned, this movie is great. I would spend $13-$16 for a movie for either one of those qualities alone. However, the movie itself is.. Well, it's not the best of all of the Pirates films. It's missing a lot of the characters that viewers have come to expect to see (two main ones, specifically) and is really focused on Jack Sparrow.

Movie 2/5
3D 5/5
 - pop out effects: A few scenes that swords come out of the screen at you, etc.
 - Depth: Amazing depth to the pictures
sound 4/5
 - I am almost always very impressed with Disney's ability to uniquely use all of the speakers in a sound system. During scenes with singing, etc. the sound envelops you and you get it from all angles. Additionally, the LFE is well used and  adds a lot to the film.
overall 3.75/5

Like I said, for the value it's a good buy. It's pretty much the cost of a single movie ticket. However, if you are looking for a riveting movie as well, then you might have to spend a bit more..

The movie opens with Mr. Gibbs from the first three movies on trial for the crime of being Captain Jack Sparrow. In a surprising twist the judge turns out to be Jack himself in a thinly veiled disguise. So how is it that nobody knows what the actual judge looks like including the other magistrates sitting around him and the dozens of people in the courtroom? This scene really sums up the movie for me. The first three films by Gore Verbinski were silly and over the top but generally fun. On Stranger Tide is often just dumb.

That is in no way meant to say the Verbinski films were perfect. They most assuredly were not. In particular I felt the series ruined the Elizabeth Swann character by making her the toughest pirate captain sailing the seas. Verbinski, however, was able to keep the action fun and inventive and he was helped enormously by the great cast. It felt like the new director Rob Marshall was desperately trying to emulate Verbinski with much weaker results. The first escape sequence by Jack Sparrow may be the worst in the whole series. The fight between Jack and and his  doppleganger in the kitchen (???) seemed like a direct rip off of the first fight between Jack and Will Turner in the smithy house except not nearly as well done. There was a fight between the captive crew and Blackbeards zombies on the Queen Anne's Revenge that felt like it was a replay of the fight on the Pearl in the first movie. And I didn't like either fight. The great irony is that this weak imitation, which stands as easily the most poorly rated in the series, was the second highest grossing of the four films and 12th highest grossing film of all time.

The action is often quite daft. In one scene Jack Sparrow is tied to a coconut tree with about thirty yards of thick rope and manages to shimmy his body up to the top of the tree. He's show rising from the top of the tree which wouldn't work because he would have gotten caught up in the branches being tied up and all, He then ties the rope around a coconut and gets it to wrap around another coconut tree about 50 feet away and begins bending the tree with an inhuman level of strength. When the tree snaps back Sparrow is sent flying through the air like a Loony Tunes cartoon and for all the effort it only gained him about 30 yards which he could have just walked. There were a lot of silly over the top action sequences in the previous 3 movies but Verbinski managed to keep them fun whereas in this film they're either poor copies of better actions sequences or just dimwitted.

Perhaps the biggest problem in the film is how ill defined the characters are. Philip Swift seems like the replacement for Will Turner but with none of Turner's charm. Swift's love interest is a mermaid who we're supposed to feel sorry for having been abducted by Blackbeard except the film already established that mermaids true appearances are hideous and they drag men to their deaths, The movie can't seem to decide whether Angelica, played by Penelope Cruz's, is a master manipulator or kind hearted soul. Ian McShane is a fine actor and his initial introduction in the film is done well but his modest height hurts his physical presence and at 68 when the film came out he has a rather old and sleepy appearance. I'm a big fan of Geoffrey Rush but his Captain Barbossa just seems tired and they piled on pancake make for no apparent reason.

The flim ends as nonsensically as the rest of the film. Characters act with seemingly random motivation as if the writers just decided it would be cool if a character did something regardless if it made any sense. Despite the astronomical box office take the series simply has not set itself up for future success. I have a feeling the next flim will feel the brunt of this one and if Johnny Depp were to leave the series would be dead. There are some beautiful scenes in the movie. This is one of the most expensive movies of all times and it looks good but to spend so much money around such a dumb plot is painful. I didn't hate this movie and I watched it twice for this review but it is by far the weakest of the four Pirates movies.
None of the follow up movies to the original Pirates are as good, but they are still better than most of the movies out there.  And they all have Johnny Depp it them, so what's not to like.

I loved the first movie.  But was somewhat unhappy with the second, because it felt unfinished being that it was the first of a two part.  And the third one, while having some scenes that did WOW me, also felt unfinished and unpolished.  On Stranger Tides, partly based on a very good pirate novel, had many factors that I enjoy in the movie.  First, it was a full story.  Second, adventure, action, a story without leaning too heavily on special effects.  It also had a touch of mystery and fantasy, with the search for Voodoo, the Fountain of Youth, and mermaids.
Why one star gone?  Well, I had nothing against Penelope Cruz who came across as both beautiful and dangerous, Ian McShane as Blackbeard just seemed too...small for the part?  Edward Teach, good or bad, is seen as a cutlass carrying giant in Pirate lore, and here he comes across as a smooth talking con artist.
I did enjoy the race between the English and the Spanish to find and claim the Fountain.  And the interaction between Jack Sparrow and Hector Barbossa, played by Johnny Depp and Geoffrey Rush.  But Blackbeard is a major character and Mr. McShane just did not seem to fill the huge boots of that character.
Still a enjoyable watch.  Enjoy!
This edition of "Pirates" didn't capture me like the others. It wasn't terrible, but the story line is feeling a bit tired.

Lacked the fun and adventure of the original trilogy. Felt thrown together and written over a weekend. The parts I COULD follow were so disjointed they didn't make any sense and I hardly found myself laughing at any of the attempts at humor. It felt like diet Pirates of the Caribbean where the sword fights were on solid ground instead of giant wheels rolling through the forrest, horrible sea creatures were hot women with sometimes visible flippers instead of enormous ship-devouring tentacle beasts, and the scary boat full of undead pirates were just men with weird bumps on their skin instead of being made out of various fish parts or turning to skeleton in the moonlight. It was all like they took the wow factor out of all the elements from the originals then slapped the same name on it. And even tho they tried to shift the main character to Jack Sparrow after losing Will and Elizabeth,  he still played like a sidekick to the story and thus leaving the movie with no clear hero or villain to root for or against. By the end, I really didn't care who won or died and the worst part is it left the ending unfinished and open ended, yet I have no desire to see it through. SPOILER: The only person I cared about even just a little was the Christian boy who fell in love with the mermaid, and they don't explain at all what happens to him. In fact that relationship was so rushed that I didn't know what to think by the end to even wager a guess of his outcome. Did she save him? Did she turn him into a merman? Did she drown and eat him and was misleading him the whole time? Any are possible because I have nothing to go on.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: 1/5: "Rating is for Disney, not the movie itself.  While other studios are generous with digital copies being of HD quality, Disney continues to be unbelievably cheap with SD quality digital copies (as was the case with the digital code for this movie).  Unless a Disney movie states clearly that the digital code is HD, I will not purchase it.  Also, in protest, I will NEVER purchase a digital copy of a Disney movie on iTunes or anywhere else.  Disney is obviously hoping you will buy the same movie in several different formats just to make their cash register ring.  How greedy can you get.  Good thing Disney lags almost all major studios these days on the quality of their movie offerings.  If it wasn't for Marvel movies, Disney would be stone dead in the business world of quality movie production."

UPDATED REVIEW AS OF FEB. 25, 2014: 5/5: "Today, Disney launched DisneyMoviesAnywhere.  When I registered at that site and linked that site with my iTunes account, it not only gave me "The Incredibles" in HD for free, but it also upgraded to HD the following Disney digital movies which I had in my iTunes account in SD format: (1) this movie, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides; (2) Marvel's Iron Man 2; and (3) Marvel's The Avengers.  Also, when I entered the Disney Movie Rewards codes for Alice in Wonderland, Tron: Legacy and the Lone Ranger on Disney's new site, it automatically gave me the HD versions of those movies, whereas, before, I was unable to redeem such codes using iTunes (the digital codes for the first two movies had expired long ago and the digital code for The Lone Ranger was redeemed on vudu.com and did not work on iTunes).  The bottom line is that Ultraviolet has really taken off and UV digital codes very frequently redeem in full HD, not SD like Disney previously did through iTunes.  Disney and Apple apparently have teamed up and have decided to jointly promote an aggressive alternative to UV.  We customers are the beneficiaries of this competition.  Since I now have this Disney movie in HD in iTunes, I am once again a happy customer and, for that reason, revised my rating accordingly.  HINT: You may need to "sign out" of your iTunes account on your iPad and then sign back in for your linked "SD" Disney movies to appear in iTunes in an upgraded HD format."

I chose a four star rating because this movie is a great blend of action, comedy, adventure, and mystery. Although, I did only four stars because the first half of this movie is basically only about some sword fighting, and explaining the Fountain of Youth. Once you get past all of the explanations though, this is a great movie that includes mermaids, holy water, Blackbeard and Barbosa's ways, and even some history related topics! The British were trying to get to the fountain before the Spanish, so for people who like a little twist of history, this is good.
I liked how they related this movie to history a little bit, and incorporated the pirates cleverly, except the first half, saturated with explanations, was somewhat of a disappointment. I would recommend this product to people twelve, thirteen, fourteen years of age. It is quite descriptive sometimes, except it's filled with good action later. It's probably too violent or graphic for younger kids. My ten year old sister watched it with me, and vowed it was the worst pirate movie out of all four just because of the frightening mermaid scene. (She got quite scared.)
I would say this movie is second best to Curse of the Black Pearl out of the four movies. This movie was a little bit more boring at the beginning, but in the middle of the second half, it definitely met my expectations. For a teenager who is looking for a movie with a variety of entertainment possibilities, this is good, but be careful of youngsters watching this.

Given the silly script, fairly flimsy plot and some questionable acting I can enjoy the films. Well I did find some joy in the first two, but that third movie seems to be the problem child for most series. Either way this movie diverts from the previous films in terms of overall production. It seems really stiff and thrown together. They had a great actor, Ian McShane, and they still couldn't give him any compelling dialogue or redeeming qualities. Cruz's character seems to have undying loyalty for a father who shows no flicker of love or affection yet she's willing to risk her life and curse jack for saving it in spite of her father. The comedy is force and sparse, the fight scenes are half hearted and the mysteries are just splayed out instead of slowly revealed. Like me and probably most rational people this series seems exhausted mentally and sometimes physically. It's no wonder that Bloom and Knightley didn't sign on for it. Depp clearly just has some secret pact with disney that he can't or won't opt out of seeing as he appears in another blunder in The Lone Ranger. Ultimately it's a fruitless endeavor even if what you're looking for, and I was, a cheap pirate laugh with some entertaining back and forth while swashbuckling. Just rewatch the first two and go play Black Flag. (Or watch Muppet Treasure Island because Tim Curry is 5x the pirate these guys are)

My wife doesn't like me drinking rum. To try to satisfy my craving for the sweet imbibing nectar I watch this movie. That scene where Barbossa takes the bootleg from his peg leg. Ahh! I feel at home! Seeing it in 3D only makes the experience more real - as if I'm right there, sipping from that very bottle, drawing ever closer to a molasses-induced coma. Then those bloody mermaids come! Oof! Some people can't resist that screeching but slap the head of a sea witch with a bottle of rum and you'll be fine. Some parts of the galaxy think that towels are the ultimate instrument of leverage, but let me tell you - it's rum. And nothing says "rum" like Jack Sparrow ... and Barbossa's keg-in-a-peg. Ahhhh.... Ruuuummmm.

Which I expected since there was a horse carriage chase scene with fire, explosions and debris everywhere but none of that debris really came popping out at you. The best 3d moment is on Black Beard's ship when he points the sword straight at the screen and starts controlling the ship, also when Penlope Cruz's character threw a sword through the door on Black Beard's ship. Those are your two really great 3D parts, the last half or third of the film with the mermaids and the island jungle has some really good depth on the foliage and the final scene in general.

Overall a Good movie with mostly average 3D that has two really good pop out moments.

I enjoyed the original Pirates trilogy but could not shake the impression that the latter two films were written on the fly. That does not appear to be the case with the present film however. It approaches the first film in the quality of script and tight story telling.

All the elements that make the Pirates movies so enjoyable are present. There is a ton of madcap action, supernatural thrills, and wonderfully likeable characters. The mermaid hunt/attack scene is the highlight here with the contrast between the beauty and ferocity of the mermaids being delightfully creepy. On the other hand I'm not really sure I understood what was going on with that whole mermaid Spider-Man webbing thing. Only a handful of the characters from the original trilogy return. Of course, you can't have a Pirates movie without Johnny Depp playing Jack Sparrow. The new characters did not entirely come up to the level set by the originals. Ian McShane made a fine villain but the gorgeous Penelope Cruz is not really an adequate successor to Keira Knightly as a female lead.

Highly recommended. If you liked the original trilogy or even only the first one you'll probably like this one too. Be sure to watch through the credits for the sequel hook at the end.

Very enjoyable to watch, the acting and story was great. I definite recommend watching it especially if you are a fan of the franchise. The new actors are great and Johnny Depp is fantastic as always.

In a world of one extreme opinion or the extreme opposite, there doesn't seem to be a lot of patience for middle of the road.  When Pirates 4 came out, there seemed to be a lot of that.  It was either the worst thing Johnny Depp has ever pranced across, or, at least, so much better than the last couple of sequels.  Well friends, I come to make a declaration: It was okay.  As a big budget blockbuster with a some laughs and derring do, the movie works just fine.

Is it amazing?  Not really.  I really dig Johnny Depp as Captain Jack Sparrow.  He clearly has a lot of fun with the role and is a great character to watch.  That said, Captain Jack is not the sort of character that needs to carry the movie.  Sure, he can carry it based soley on his charisma, but as far as how big a role he plays, he works a little better in smaller doses.

Orlando Bloom and Kiera Knightley aren't around for this adventure, so Captain Jack is the man.  A missionary named Phillip is there to presumably take on the Will Turner-esque role, but other than simply to shoe-horn a romance between him and the mermaid; he doesn't add much to the proceedings.  Yes, a movie like this full of scalawags and scoundrels needs a character that provides a moral center to the movie, but Phillip could be removed from the flick and it would not change anything.

The action itself is fine and full of swashbuckling fun. Yet I just couldn't help but notice a lack of sizzle and panache to the set pieces that Gore Verbinski brought to the original three Pirate movies.  They are exciting, but not quite as inventive as some of those great sequences.

All that said, I did enjoy the movie.  The one problem I had with the original Pirate movies was that there's a bit of bloatedness about them.  Especially the third one.  This one is way more straightforward and I really appreciated that it felt like more of a self-contained adventure that's not tripping over itself to set up sequels.

The storyline is interesting enough.  I always enjoy the search for lost treasures and artifacts and the search for the Fountain of Youth is always good for this type of genre. They have a lot of fun with it and the twists and turns are clever, as is a good deal of the dialogue.

I really like the cast of these movies.  Captain Jack, as always, is a pleasure, even if he shouldn't be carrying the film.  It's always good to see master Gibbs and Captain Barbossa is always a blast.  These movies would not be the same without him.  As for the newcomers, Penelope Cruz I can take or leave.  I've never quite gotten the love for her, but whatever.  She's fine here.  Blackbeard is a nice addition to this motley cast of misfits and is adequately intimidating and evil; thought not quite as to the level of Davy Jones in Dead Man's Chest.

It's not great, but it's not horrible either.  It's a perfectly fine adventure film that's perfect for a lazy Saturday afternoon.  There's enough fun and interesting ideas in the movie to keep it afloat (so to speak), but it just doesn't quite reach the heights of something more memorable.  The blu-ray looks and sounds great and I don't regret having a copy sitting on the shelf to throw in when I'm in the mood for some Captain Jack.

The book by Tim Powers, On Stranger Tides has more zombies, witchcraft, blood, and sea battles then they could possibly fit into one movie. There is a mad doctor carrying around his dead wife's head (to bring her back to life), a puppeteer that gets press-ganged into being a pirate ( and ends up being a pretty good cook as well as pirate), lots of voodoo, and (warning) don't eat any chicken that has a spell written on it's beak. Too bad this movie only resembles the book in mentioning the Fountain of Youth, and Blackbeard. If you read the book you will ask why the movie is so underwhelming. And the puppeteer is a better pirate than Jack Sparrow. Guess that's why they left him out.
After a couple sequels that lacked the fun of the original, this movie recaptures a lot of the comedy and has a lighter, more fun, not-so-weird plot line.

Funny and entertaining, as usual.
One or two parts are, in my opinion, to scary, though brief, for children under 13.

When i had first heard the reviews that were coming out for this movie i was very skeptical to say the least. I loved the first three Pirates of the Caribbean films. Even the third one "At Worlds End" which also received many negative reviews for it being lost and too weird i also loved. Now on to the fourth installment, "On Stranger Tides". Anyone who is an avid fan of the Pirates of the Caribbean series like myself will almost with out a doubt like this movie. It takes off right where the third film left off, and it follows in the same vain of the previous films. Lots of action and witty comedy for you to enjoy. Even though Orlando Bloom and Keira Knightly are absent from this film, i have to say they aren't missed. Penelope Cruz and Ian McShane do a great job, both feel like they fit right in with the story, and Bloom and Knightly are forgotten about within about a few minutes of watching this film. Now the reason for the above title "A good continuation." Is because this movie seems like it's more of a bridge towards the next film, which has just been recently announced. It feels more like just a side story so everyone can get caught up with whats going on in the main story line. But that being said it's a very good and very well thought out side story. And it definitely fits in the series. All in all this is a great film, and a must watch for anyone who loves the Pirates series.

Unless you really feel like you have to see every one this one is worth ignoring. I've seen the others and mostly they are a lot of fun. I heard this one was bad but after a trip to Kauai and wandering around some of the areas where it was filmed I had that curiosity to see what the area would look like in film. I felt like I worked hard (staying awake) to get to the last 10 minutes or so to spot the location. Unlike the first two, the special effects are so redundant that it feels like being numb staring at another sequence. The thrill is gone folks...... don't waste your time

So Jack Sparrow is back, again conning his way out of trouble.  Barbosa and Gibbs Too!  The beautiful Penelope Cruz plays a pirates daughter who knew Captain Jack in the past.  These movies have all been entertaining and fun but I'm afraid none compare to The Curse of the Black Pearl.  The greatest surprise was the absolutely perfect rendering of the mermaids.  The make-up, costuming, and story line are fantastic for these creatures.  I'd watch it again just to see them!  Jack's father reappears and is just what you'd expect from a relative of Captain Jacks.

Anyway a good film that kept my attention for the 2 hours it ran and the time did seem to fly by which means it must have been a good film and other than a few loose ends, which I hope will be addressed in a later film, it was satisfying.

The wife, like MANY wives, is somewhat of a fan of Mr. Depp.  So when this movie came out in 3D, we had to purchase it.

So the good:  it's a solid 3D experience, and the sound is excellent.

The not so good:  it's a bit darker in it's overtones, which affects 3D quality somewhat.  It's good, it's just not great.

The sound helps make that up, and if you're a series fan (or have a wife who drools over...er...is a fan of Johnny Depp) then this is absolutely worth purchasing.
...I'm a bad critic, just love movies. Love the Disney Pirates series as do my two boys and look forward to more.

Wacky intro - at sea, in the court of the Spanish king, "How soon can you sail?" "Weeth thee tide." Brrrr... First view of London, Jack in court, jack in the king's palace, Jack making an escape in a horse cart, at The Captain's Daughter pub, at the dock, then trying to organize a mutiny on Blackbeard's boat... ulp! Great Keith Richards cameo - "Does this face look like it's been to the Fountain of Youth?" - although it's not as good as the one in Part 3 when he plays the guitar dramatically. Great drunken Captain Jack Sparrow - "I can name fingers and point names." Cool interaction with Penelope Cruz. "I'm your first mate." "Was I your first? I've often wondered." Black Pearl in a bottle now - complete with monkey. "I still hate that monkey!!"

"The lies I told you were not lies."
"You lied to me by telling the truth? That's very good. May I use that?"

Strange plot, strange alliances, strange zombie crew (the quartermaster, a white zombie). Freaky battles with mermaids. Weird moment when the Fountain of Youth sucks the life out of Edward Teach. Priest is killed again and again - three times? Christ-like, I guess. Last word of the film: "Savvy?"

Watch to the end of the credits - there's a missing scene - Jack's voodoo doll washes up on the island Penelope Cruz was stranded on. Ha ha!! Bloopers scenes, not so great, although one where Depp uses the sword to remove Cruz's tri-corner hat is kind of funny...
Just kind of went on and on and on. Felt all jumbled up and going no where. I always like Johnny Depp but this didn't keep our interst going.
now this is a family friendly movie, and enjoyable to watch over and over and over.... and over again, e
